bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Anita Isaacs is a professor whose research has focused on politics and democratization in Latin America with particular emphasis on Ecuador and Guatemala. She worked in the Ford Foundation's Developing Countries Program Division from 1985 to 1988.

Isaacs joined the Ford Foundation in 1985 as an Assistant Program Officer in its Developing Countries Program Division. She was promoted to a Program Officer in 1987. Her work at the Foundation focused on grant making in Latin America and the Caribbean.

After leaving the Ford Foundation, Isaacs worked as an Adjunct Professor in the Department of Political Science at New York University in 1988 before starting her career at Haverford College. From 1988 to 1994, she worked as an Assistant Professor in Haverford's Department of Political Science before becoming an Associate Professor. In 2006, she became a Benjamin R. Collins Professor of Social Science.
Isaacs earned a B.A. in political science from McGill University in 1980, a M.Phil. in Latin American studies from Oxford University in 1982, and a D.Phil. in politics from Oxford in 1985.
